articles.title: Joint Conference on Astronomy
articles.summary: This document announces a Joint Conference on Astronomy, bringing together four prominent astronomical organizations. These include the Western Amateur Astronomers, Astronomical Association of Northern California, Association of Lunar and Planetary Observers, and the Astronomical Society of the Pacific.
keywords: Association of Lunar and Planetary Observers

articles.title: REGISTRATION:
articles.summary: The article outlines registration details for an event, encouraging pre-registration at $9.00 to minimize check-in time and aid conference planning. Attendees can also register at the door for $10.00. The deadline for pre-registration is July 20, 1978.

articles.title: CONFIRMATION OF YOUR PRE-REGISTRATION:
articles.summary: This document serves as a confirmation of pre-registration for an event, detailing essential information for attendees. It outlines what pre-registrants will receive, such as event confirmation, Vandenberg field trip status, parking passes, campus housing check-in instructions, and a campus map. The notice also states that pre-registrations received after July 20th will not receive a confirmation.

articles.title: TRANSPORTATION TO SAN LUIS OBISPO:
articles.summary: The article outlines transportation options to San Luis Obispo for attendees not traveling by personal vehicle. It highlights services provided by Amtrak, Greyhound Bus Lines, and Swift Airlines. All specified carrier terminals are located just a short taxi ride from the convention site.

articles.title: HOUSING:
articles.summary: This document outlines housing options for a conference, detailing clean and modern resident halls near the convention site available from July 26th to 30th. These accommodations were inspected and deemed convenient and pleasant. For those preferring off-campus stays, a list of motels in the San Luis Obispo area is available upon request, with a strong recommendation for early reservations.

articles.title: CAMPER AND HOUSE TRAILER PARKING:
articles.summary: This document prohibits overnight parking of campers and house trailers on campus. It advises individuals to seek public and private sites, offering to provide information upon pre-registration. It also strongly recommends making advance reservations for camping, especially during the busy summer months.

articles.title: PARKING:
articles.summary: Parking lots are located close to the convention site. A parking permit is required for Thursday and Friday, as these are regular school days, but permits are not needed on Saturday or Sunday. Attendees should indicate their permit needs on the registration form.

articles.title: FIELD TRIPS:
articles.summary: Two parallel field trips are scheduled for Friday afternoon, July 28th. The main trip will be to Vandenberg Air Force Base, with a secondary option to visit Hearst Castle for a unique experience.

articles.title: VANDENBERG:
articles.summary: This document describes a limited-attendance field trip to Vandenberg via chartered Greyhound buses, as private vehicles cannot be accommodated. The approximately 6-hour tour will include a facilities briefing and visits to Thor Missile storage, a Minuteman Silo Launch Complex, and Launch Complex #6, the West Coast launch site for the Space Shuttle. Participants are strongly advised to pre-register early due to the first-come, first-serve participation limit.

articles.title: HEARST CASTLE:
articles.summary: This document provides a detailed guide for visiting Hearst Castle in San Simeon, California, located less than an hour from a convention site. It outlines three distinct tours covering various parts of the estate, including gardens, pools, guest houses, and the castle's interior, along with their respective prices. Visitors must arrange their own transportation and make reservations for the specified date of July 28, 1978, directly through Ticketron.

articles.title: DINING FACILITIES:
articles.summary: The convention provides convenient and high-quality dining facilities near the site, offering on-campus options like a cafeteria, restaurant, and snack facilities, plus a guide to local eateries. A packaged meal program for the complete conference, priced at $30 per person, includes seven meals from Thursday evening to Saturday evening (July 27-29), featuring a Luncheon Banquet. Complimentary coffee and punch breaks are also provided.

articles.title: BANQUET:
articles.summary: The W.A.A. Annual Banquet will be held as a luncheon, featuring keynote speaker Mr. Ashley McDermott and the presentation of the G. Bruce Blair Gold Medal and AANC awards. The cost is included in the package food price, or tickets can be purchased separately, and attendees with special dietary requirements should notify the conference committee.

articles.title: STAR PARTY:
articles.summary: A star party will be held on Friday night at the top of San Luis Peak (Madonna Mountain), overlooking San Luis Obispo. The private property is owned by Mr. Alex Madonna of the renowned Madonna Inn. Everyone is welcome to attend the event, regardless of whether they bring their own equipment.

articles.title: TELESCOPE EXHIBIT AND COMPETITION:
articles.summary: An invitation has been extended for individuals to exhibit and/or enter telescopes and related equipment into a competition. The AANC will host, judge, and present awards for this program, which is a traditional part of their annual conference.

articles.title: ASTROPHOTOGRAPHY EXHIBITS:
articles.summary: An astrophotography exhibit will be held in the auditorium lobby, organized by John Sanford and Charles Townsend. Participants are welcomed and encouraged to join by contacting their Society President or directly reaching out to the organizers.

articles.title: GROUP PHOTO:
articles.summary: A group photograph is scheduled to be taken on Thursday afternoon, July 27th. Attendees interested in obtaining copies of this photo can order them at the registration desk during the convention.

articles.title: PROCEEDINGS:
articles.summary: The proceedings from "ASTRONOMY WEST '78" are scheduled for publication, including all papers submitted in camera-ready format. Copies can be ordered at the registration desk and will be mailed directly to purchasers after printing and binding.

articles.title: SOCIETY WORKSHOP:
articles.summary: An experimental workshop has been scheduled for the amateur astronomical community to foster a free interchange of information. It aims to help officers, directors, and members address common organizational challenges, programs, membership, and legal liabilities by sharing solutions found by other organizations.

articles.title: RECREATIONAL FACILITIES:
articles.summary: The campus offers on-site recreational facilities like tennis courts and bowling alleys. Additionally, popular coastal destinations such as Morro Bay and Avila Beach are conveniently located just a 20 to 30 minute drive away, providing further recreational opportunities.

articles.title: COLLEGE CREDIT:
articles.summary: Cal Poly's Physics Department is offering a special 600 Series course, providing college credit for attending a conference, subject to a nominal registration fee. This credit is not for graduation but is recognized for professional educational purposes, with enrollment required by 2 PM on Thursday, July 27.

articles.title: CALL FOR PAPERS:
articles.summary: This document is a call for papers and talks, inviting individuals to present their research or experiences at an upcoming program. Submissions must follow an approved format and be received by July 20th to be included in the proceedings. Further instructions and forms are available through local society presidents or by contacting the Papers Chairman in Santa Rosa, CA.

articles.title: SCHEDULE:
articles.summary: A conference is scheduled to begin on Thursday, July 27th, at 9 AM, with check-in starting at 8 AM. The event will span approximately 35 hours, concluding at noon on Sunday, July 30th.

articles.title: ASTRONOMY WEST 78
articles.summary: This document is an invitation to 'ASTRONOMY WEST '78,' a major West Coast Astronomical Conference taking place from July 27-30 at California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo. This joint conference, co-sponsored by Western Amateur Astronomers (WAA), Astronomical Association of Northern California (AANC), Association of Lunar and Planetary Observers (ALPO), and Astronomical Society of the Pacific (ASP), promises a comprehensive program including papers, speakers, field trips, workshops, and a star party. Attendees are encouraged to pre-register.
keywords: Association of Lunar and Planetary Observers

articles.title: WESTERN AMATEUR ASTRONOMERS
articles.summary: The Western Amateur Astronomers is an established organization that serves as an affiliation for various amateur astronomical societies. For over a quarter century, it has been dedicated to uniting and supporting astronomers in the Western region.

articles.title: MAIL TO: WAA REGISTRATION, c/o 1110 Petaluma Hill Road, Santa Rosa, CA 95404
articles.summary: This document is a registration form for an event organized by WAA, detailing various fee-based options including pre-registration, a university meal package, a banquet, and a Vandenberg field trip. It also gathers attendee information for accommodation needs like parking passes and motel guides, society affiliation, and outlines payment instructions, including a separate section for California Polytechnic State University housing reservations and cancellation policy.

articles.title: CAMPUS HOUSING RESERVATION FORM
articles.summary: This document is a campus housing reservation form designed for attendees of a specific program. It requires personal details such as name and address, along with preferences for accommodation type (single, double, couple, children) and their respective daily rates. The form also asks for arrival and departure dates and explicitly mentions the 'Joint Conference on Astronomy' as the program being attended.

articles.title: POSSIBLE COMET DISCOVERED BY DON MACHHOLZ OF LOS GATOS
articles.summary: Don Machholz of Los Gatos possibly discovered a comet on September 12 at the Loma Prieta Site after extensive hunting. Initial observations on September 12 and 13 detailed its diffuse, fuzzy appearance, magnitude (11, then 10.7), and movement, though it remains unconfirmed with no orbital data yet. Confirmation is anticipated on September 14.
